questions.text: During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about? Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge Watch for the persistence of Anosmia Watch for headache and nasal discharge Monitor glucose levels Watch for Sinusitis like symptoms
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 3, 4 and 5

questions.text: A woman with hysteria who was hyperventilating developed carpo-pedal spasms. What could be the likely cause for this?
questions.explanation:
Category

Features

Cause

Neurological
  • Dizziness
  • Mental confusion
  • Paresthesias
  • Circumoral numbness
  • Seizures (severe cases)
  • Due to reduced cerebral blood flow
  • From rapid ↓ PaCO2
  • May occur without hypoxemia

Cardiovascular
  • Chest tightness/pain
  • Palpitations
  • Arrhythmias
  • Possible ECG changes
  • Due to coronary vasoconstriction
  • ↓ ionized calcium effects
  • Bohr effect on O2 delivery

Neuromuscular
  • Carpopedal spasms
  • Tetany
  • Muscle twitching
  • Weakness
  • From ↓ ionized calcium
  • Enhanced nerve excitability
  • Similar to hypocalcemia

Laboratory
  • ↑ pH
  • ↓ PaCO2
  • ↓ Ionized calcium
  • ↓ K+, ↓ PO4
  • Acute: ↓ HCO3- by 2 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Chronic: ↓ HCO3- by 4-5 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Electrolyte shifts into cells

Management

Underlying Disease:

  • Treat primary condition
  • Address anxiety if present
  • Manage sepsis if present
 

Hyperventilation Syndrome:

  • Reassurance
  • Rebreathing techniques
  • Paper bag breathing if needed
  • β-blockers if needed
  • Primary focus on the underlying cause
  • Avoid sedatives for anxiety
  • Monitor during mechanical ventilation
  • Adjust ventilator settings if needed
  • Regular monitoring of blood gases
  • Address psychological factors

questions.text: A diabetic woman is admitted due to persistent vomiting. She gives a history of consuming food from outside. On evaluation, her blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings. What is the cause of her ABG findings? pH - 7.52 HCO 3 - 30 meq/L PaCO 2 - 20 mmHg Na- 123 mEq/L K- 3.2 mEq/L CI- 67 mEq/L

A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with laboured breathing. ECG shows tall, tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. pH-7.14, pCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3- 5 mEq/L
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with a fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest x-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Atypical Pneumonia

Outpatients

Hospitalised Patients

Includes M.pneumoniae C.pneumoniae, and Legionella species.

Common causes:

S.pneumoniae, M.pneumoniae

H. influenzae, C.pneumoniae, Respiratory viruses (influenza, RSV).

Non-ICU

ICU Patients

Similar pathogens to outpatients, plus Legionella species.

Pathogens include S.pneumoniae, S. aureus (including MRSA), Legionella species, gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae.

Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA):
  • It can cause CAP, often complicating influenza infections.
  • Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) has emerged as a significant cause of necrotizing pneumonia.

Pneumococcal Pneumonia:
  • Higher risk in elderly patients, and those with comorbidities like dementia, heart failure, cerebrovascular disease, alcoholism, smoking, COPD, and HIV infection.

CA-MRSA Pneumonia:
  • More likely in patients with prior skin infections or following viral illnesses.

Enterobacteriaceae:
  • Common in patients recently hospitalized, those treated with antibiotics, or those with comorbidities like alcoholism, heart failure, or renal failure.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
  • Found in patients with severe structural lung diseases such as bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or advanced COPD.

Legionella Infection:
  • Associated with risk factors like diabetes, hematologic malignancies, cancer, severe renal disease, HIV, smoking, male gender, and recent travel (air conditioners, showers, hotels, cruise ships). It is an important cause of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. The absolute eosinophil count is >5000/µL. Chest x-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?

A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - 4

questions.text: Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it? Arterial pH Venous pH Venous pO2 Venous pCO2
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - 1,2

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Fixed central airway obstruction

Loop Type

Expiratory Curve

Inspiratory Curve

Example Conditions

Normal

Symmetrical, rounded

Healthy lungs

Scooped (concave)

Normal

COPD, asthma

Fixed Upper Airway Obstruction

Tracheal stenosis, large goiter

Variable Extrathoracic Obstruction (Option D)

Normal

Flattened

Vocal cord dysfunction, laryngeal tumor

Variable Intrathoracic Obstruction (Option C)

Flattened

Normal

Tracheomalacia, bronchogenic tumor

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactive test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B  - A

On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

(U) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L)

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure – Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause?

A patient with a history of fever for the past 4 days and sudden onset of breathlessness was admitted to ICU as he was deteriorating. He was unresponsive to the incremental flow rate of oxygen and his oxygen saturation was progressively decreasing. A chest x-ray was ordered and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with the following arterial blood gas (ABG) results: pH 7.55, PaCO 2 40 mmHg, HCO 3 - 32 mEq/L. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
Which of the following findings from a pleural fluid aspirate will suggest an exudative pleural effusion? Normal values Total S. Protein: 6-8 gm% S.LDH: 140-280 IU S. glucose: 140-200

options.label: A
options.text: Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > ⅔ of serum LDH

options.label: B
options.text: Pleural fluid protein = 4.5 gm% and glucose = 30 mg%

options.label: C
options.text: Pleural fluid LDH = 90IU and glucose = 30 mg%

options.label: D
options.text: Pleural fluid protein = 3.5gm% and glucose = 90 mg%

questions.correct_answer: A. Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > ⅔ of serum LDH
questions.explanation:
Radiological investigation

X-ray:

  • 200 mL of fluid is needed for detection on the posteroanterior (PA) view.
  • 50 mL of fluid may lead to blunting of the costophrenic angle on the lateral view.
  • A homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle is typical.
  • This appearance is marked by a curved upper border, known as the Ellis S-shaped curve.
  • Obliteration of cardiophrenic angle.

Ultrasound: More effective than X-ray in detecting fluid presence, showing a clear hypoechoic space indicative of transudate and moving densities suggesting exudate.

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Additional Tests for Exudative Effusions
  • Appearance description
  • Glucose level, If Glucose <60 mg/dL Consider:
    • Malignancy
    • Bacterial infections (empyema)
    • Rheumatoid pleuritis
  • Differential cell count
  • Microbiologic studies
  • Cytology

Standard Peculiarities

  • Heart Failure: NT-proBNP level > 1500 pg/mL indicates effusion due to congestive heart failure
  • Parapneumonic Effusion: Key criteria include:
    • Loculated pleural fluid
    • Pleural fluid pH < 7.20
    • Pleural fluid glucose < 3.3 mmol/L (< 60 mg/dL) ( Option B, C)
    • Positive Gram stain or culture results
    • Presence of visible pus
  • Tuberculous Pleuritis: Diagnosis confirmed by high TB markers in pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase > 40 IU/L or interferon γ > 140 pg/mL)

questions.text: The following patient has presented after chest trauma. On examination, crepitus is felt. The clinical diagnosis is?
Which of the following imaging tests should be performed to confirm a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Evaluation

 

PE symptoms are nonspecific, often leading to excessive use of CT pulmonary angiograms. Age-adjusted d-dimer testing is recommended for patients over 50 years with low-to-moderate PE probability.

D-Dimer

A sensitive but nonspecific test for PE. Elevated levels indicate possible PE but can also occur with conditions like MI, pneumonia, or sepsis. Normal d-dimer helps rule out PE.

Electrocardiogram (ECG)

Common findings include sinus tachycardia(most common) and the S1Q3T3 sign (most specific) (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, inverted T wave in lead III). T-wave inversion in V1 to V4 suggests RV strain or ischemia.

Venous Ultrasonography

Uses loss of vein compressibility as a key indicator for diagnosing DVT, which is associated with PE. Doppler imaging can assess blood flow dynamics.

Chest X-ray

Often normal but may show specific signs like Westermark’s sign (focal oligemia), Hampton’s hump (wedge-shaped pleural density), or Palla’s sign (enlarged pulmonary artery).

Chest radiograph demonstrating focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign) in the right lung (area between white arrowheads) and a prominent right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign) (black arrow).

The chest radiograph demonstrates a wedge-shaped opacity (arrow) in the right middle lobe consistent with Hampton hump.

Chest CT with Contrast

 

The primary imaging test. It offers high-resolution visualisation of pulmonary vasculature. RV enlargement on CT indicates a higher risk of mortality.

Lung Scanning

A second-line test, mostly for patients who can’t tolerate contrast. High-probability perfusion scans (two or more segmental perfusion defects) strongly suggest PE.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) Imaging

MR venography with gadolinium can diagnose DVT when ultrasound is inconclusive, though MR pulmonary angiography (Option D) is less reliable for smaller PEs.

Echocardiography

It is not reliable (Option A) for directly diagnosing PE but useful for detecting mimicking conditions. McConnell’s sign (RV-free wall hypokinesis) is an indirect sign of PE.

CT Pulmonary Angiography

Identifies intraluminal filling defects or abrupt vessel occlusion.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after an accident in which he sustained a fracture of the femur. The oxygen saturation in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Diffuse petechiae are noted on examination. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fat Embolism Causes

Blunt trauma: Accounts for 90% of cases, especially involving extremity fractures.

 

Associated conditions:

  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Burns
  • Joint reconstruction surgeries
  • Liposuction
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Decompression sickness
  • Parenteral lipid infusion
  • Sickle cell crisis
  • Pathologic fractures

Increased risk factors (in trauma patients):

  • Age 30 years or younger
  • Closed femur fracture
  • Multiple long-bone fractures

questions.text: In patients affected by COVID-19, which of the following patterns is frequently observed in chest CT scans?

CO-RADS

Suspicion Level

CT findings

CO-RADS 0

 

Technically inadequate

CO-RADS 1

No

Normal or non-infectious abnormalities

CO-RADS 2

Low

Abnormalities consistent with infections other than Covid-19

CO-RADS 3

Indeterminate

Unclear whether covid-19 is present

CO-RADS 4

High

Abnormalities suspicious for covid-19

CO-RADS 5

Very high

Typical covid-19

CO-RADS 6

PCR+

options.label: B

questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Pneu

Causes of Direct Injury (Air-Lung Interface)

Causes of Indirect Injury (Blood-Lung Interface)

Inhalation of toxic gases and chemicals

Sepsis

Aspiration of gastric contents

Fat embolism syndrome

Near-drowning

Transfusion-related lung injury

High-pressure mechanical ventilation

Pancreatitis

Radiation therapy

Inhalation of smoke or particulate matter

questions.text: A 45-year patient working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. Diagnosis is?
The flow-volume curve of a patient after spirometry is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:
questions.explanation:
Test

Details

Spirometry/PFTs
  • Best initial test
  • IOC
  • Obstructive pattern
    • Reversible with short-acting β2-agonists (SABAs)
  • Findings:
    • FEV1/FVC < 70%
    • ↓ FEV1
    • Normal or ↓ FVC
    • ↑ Residual Volume (RV)
    • ↑ Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
    • Normal or ↑ Diffusing Capacity of Lung for Carbon Monoxide (DLCO)
  • Reversibility:
    • Increase in FEV1 ≥ 12% and >200 mL with SABA (albuterol)
  • PFTs between exacerbations: Often normal

Methacholine Challenge
  • Tests for bronchial hyperresponsiveness
  • Positive if ≥20% decrease in FEV1
  • Sensitive but not specific

Arterial blood gas

  • Early
    • Respiratory alkalosis (↓ PaCO2, ↑ pH) due to hyperventilation
  • Late
    • Respiratory acidosis due to muscle fatigue (normalizing PaCO2, normalizing pH, ↓ PaO2)

Chest X-ray

  • Normal appearance to hyperinflation with flattening of the diaphragm

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the OPD with fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough with red currant jelly sputum for the last two days. On examination, there was bronchial breathing on the right side, increased vocal fremitus, increased vocal resonance, and a dull note on percussion. The patient’s plain radiograph is shown below. Which is the most likely causative agent?
Identify the condition in the following X-ray.
A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia

options.label: B
options.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia

options.label: C
options.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia

options.label: D
options.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia

questions.text: A patient with a history of pneumonia develops pleural effusion. What is the expected finding in the pleural analysis for parapneumonic effusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Pleural protein/plasma protein ratio less than 0.5

options.label: B
options.text: Pleural LDH less than 2/3rd of plasma LDH

options.label: D
options.text: Pleural LDH less than 0.6 of plasma LDH

questions.explanation:
Parapneumonic effusion

Definition:

  • A parapneumonic effusion is a pleural effusion that occurs in association with bacterial pneumonia, lung abscess, or bronchiectasis.
  • These effusions develop in about 40-60% of patients with bacterial pneumonia.

Types:
  • Parapneumonic effusions can be categorized into three stages: simple (uncomplicated), complicated, and empyema.
    • Simple parapneumonic effusions, the pleural fluid is sterile and can resolve with antibiotic therapy alone.
    • Complicated parapneumonic effusions contain bacteria and require drainage in addition to antibiotics.
    • Empyema represents the most advanced stage where frank pus is present in the pleural space.

Diagnostic Criteria:

Simple Parapneumonic Effusion
  • Appearance: Serous
  • PMN++, sterile fluid (negative bacterial culture)
  • pH >7.3, LDH <500 U/L, glucose >80 mg/dL
  • Fluid-glucose: serum-glucose >0.5

Complicated Parapneumonic Effusion
  • Appearance: Turbid
  • PMN++, bacterial culture may be + or -
  • pH <7.1, LDH >1000 U/L, glucose <40 mg/dL
  • Fluid-glucose: serum-glucose <0.5

Empyema
  • Appearance: Pus
  • PMN++, bacterial culture positive or negative
  • pH <7.1, LDH >1000 U/L, glucose <40 mg/dL
  • Fluid-glucose: serum-glucose <0.5

Management:

  • Drain with antibiotics; small-bore drains (10-14 gauge) are often preferable. Consider thoracoscopic decortication if these fail.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema, and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids with a large bore cannula

options.label: B
options.text: Needle decompression into the 5 th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle decompression into the 5 th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
questions.explanation:
TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
    • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
      • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
      • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
      • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.

  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well’s score?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Feature

Points

Clinical signs of deep-vein thrombosis

3

Alternative diagnosis is less likely than PE

3

1.5

Immobilization >3 days or surgery in previous 4 weeks

1.5

1.5

Hemoptysis

1

Malignancy (with treatment within 6 months) or palliative

1

Interpretation

Score Range

Risk

High

>6.0

High

Intermediate

2.0 - 6.0

Intermediate

Low

<2.0

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows: pH=7.30, HCO3=10 mEq/L, paCO2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder?
questions.correct_answer: A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and is admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Non-invasive PPV should be given
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Arterial blood gases

Assess severity of hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, acidaemia; guide oxygen therapy and ventilation.

Chest X-ray

Identify complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pleural effusion.

Management

Details

Oxygen Therapy
  • Administer controlled oxygen at 24% or 28% to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa (60 mmHg) or SaO2 > 90%.
  • Regular arterial blood gas monitoring to adjust therapy.

Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV)
  • Safe for mild to moderate respiratory acidosis; helps reduce intubation need and mortality.
  • Not suitable for patients unable to protect their airway.

Bronchodilators
  • Use nebulised short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) with anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium).
  • If oxygen sensitivity is a concern, use compressed air for nebulisation.

Glucocorticoids
  • Administer oral prednisolone (30 mg for 10 days) to reduce symptoms and improve lung function.Reduces frequency and severity of exacerbations.
  • Consider osteoporosis prophylaxis for repeated courses.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Indicated for increased sputum purulence, volume, or breathlessness.
  • Use simple regimens (aminopenicillin, tetracycline, macrolide); co-amoxiclav in areas with β-lactamase organisms.

Mechanical Ventilation (Option B)
  • Consider if there is a reversible cause, no prior respiratory failure, or if NIV has failed/contraindicated.
  • Decisions should involve the patient, family, and GP.

Additional Therapy
  • Diuretics for peripheral oedema.
  • Limited evidence for intravenous aminophylline; consider arrhythmia risk.
  • Doxapram may be used short-term for low respiratory rates.

questions.text: When you are posted as an intern in the emergency department, a 67 year old man with a known case of diabetic and CKD for 15 yrs is brought to you with complaints of persistent cough, shortness of breath, fever, fatigue, and chest pain. He has been tested positive for COVID 19. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to a dedicated COVID health center? A. Respiratory rate of 33/min B. SpO 2 88% C. Multiple comorbidities D. Chest pain E. Age
questions.correct_answer: B. A, B, C & E only
questions.explanation:
Asymptomatic or Presymptomatic
  • No symptoms
  • SARS-CoV-2 test positive

Mild disease
  • Symptoms like fever, cough, taste or smell changes
  • No dyspnea

Moderate disease
  • LRTI (lower respiratory tract infection)
  • Oxygen saturation: >94%

Severe disease
  • Oxygen saturation: <94%
  • Respiratory rate: >30/min
  • Lung infiltrate >50%

Critical disease
  • Respiratory failure
  • Shock
  • Multi-organ failure

Stage

Clinical features

Respiratory rate

Oxygen saturation

Stage I

Mild cough, throat pain, fever, diarrhoea, anosmia or taste changes.

Normal

Normal

Stage II

  • Shortness of breath (dyspnea)
  • Coagulation starts (heparin has to be started)
  • >24 breaths per min
  • >30 breaths per minute (severe illness)
  • <94%
  • <90% (severe illness)

Stage III

  • ARDS (Acute respiratory distress syndrome)
  • Sepsis
  • MODS (multi-organ dysfunction syndrome)
  • Cardiogenic shock

Intubation needed

Intubation needed

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis

High anion gap (MUDPILES)

Non-anion gap (USED PART)
  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia: AKI, CKD
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option B)
  • Paracetamol poisoning
  • Iron and isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis (Option C)
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning (Option D)
  • U: Urinary diversion / Ureterenterostomy
  • S: Small Bowel Fistula, Spironolactone and K-sparing diuretics, Saline infusion (rapid infusion)
  • E: Extra Chloride
  • D: Diarrhea
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • A: Addison, Acetazolamide
  • R: RTA (Renal tubular acidosis )
  • T: Tenofovir, Topiramate

Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: What should be your subsequent course of action for the patient, who has been intubated and his X-ray as depicted in the radiograph?

options.label: C
options.text: Start antibiotics and send and samples for culture

questions.text: A 50-year-old individual who is a chronic smoker came with complaints of recurrent episodes of coughing up blood without any accompanying symptoms of fever or weight loss. On chest x-ray there were no abnormalities seen, and the sputum test is also negative for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Which of the following options could be the next effective diagnostic test?
Which of the following conditions will have an FEV₁/FVC ratio < 0.7 and FEV₁ < 80% of the predicted value along with wheezing in the morning hours and shortness of breath?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Tests for Bronchial Asthama

Test

Details

Spirometry/PFTs
  • Best initial test
  • IOC
  • Obstructive pattern
    • Reversible with short-acting β2-agonists (SABAs)
  • Findings:
    • FEV1/FVC < 70%
    • ↓ FEV1
    • Normal or ↓ FVC
    • ↑ Residual Volume (RV)
    • ↑ Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
    • Normal or ↑ Diffusing Capacity of Lung for Carbon Monoxide (DLCO)
  • Reversibility:
    • Increase in FEV1 ≥ 12% and >200 mL with SABA (albuterol)
  • PFTs between exacerbations: Often normal

Methacholine Challenge
  • Tests for bronchial hyperresponsiveness
  • Positive if ≥20% decrease in FEV1
  • Sensitive but not specific

Arterial blood gas

  • Early
    • Respiratory alkalosis (↓ PaCO2, ↑ pH) due to hyperventilation
  • Late
    • Respiratory acidosis due to muscle fatigue (normalizing PaCO2, normalizing pH, ↓ PaO2)

Chest X-ray

  • Normal appearance to hyperinflation with flattening of the diaphragm

Chest-x ray shows infiltrates in the right lung and patchy infiltrates in the left lung. A nasopharyngeal swab shows only Rhinovirus. The patient is shifted to the ICU. Which antibiotics are suitable for this patient?

CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure - Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain . CTPA was done. Which of the following non-invasive investigations will be useful to confirm the etiology of this presentation?

A 33-year-old woman is being evaluated for daytime sleepiness and memory loss which have been present for the past 1 year. Her BMI is 43, her BP is 170/98 mmHg. In an awake state, ABG shows pO2 70 mmHg, pCO2 53 mmHg, HCO3 33 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination his BMI is 41 kg/m2, BP is 160/100 mm Hg. His awake ABG analysis is given: PaO 2 = 66mm Hg PaCO 2 = 50 mm Hg HCO 3 = 28 mEq/L What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Obesity hypo-v

B

Asbestosis

questions.text: Which membrane channel is mainly affected in Cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Chloride

Mechanism

Key Features

CFTR Defect
  • Defective chloride/bicarbonate transport
  • Located in apical plasma membranes
  • F508del (phenylalanine is replaced) mutation most common (~70%)

Airway Changes
  • Depleted periciliary fluid layer
  • Thick mucus accumulation
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance

Infection Risk
  • Common pathogens: P. aeruginosa, S. aureus
  • Chronic bacterial colonization
  • Progressive bronchiectasis

Clinical Impact
  • Recurrent pneumonia
  • Progressive lung damage
  • Requires aggressive antibiotic therapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with obstructive lung disease is currently using salmeterol and tiotropium but continues to experience breathlessness and frequent exacerbations. Given her current situation, which of the following treatments would be most appropriate?
The chest X-ray shows right-sided white-out lung and contralateral tracheal deviation. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
A 55 year old shipbuilding worker presents with dyspnea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer .
  • It is not associated with smoking.

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene- CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin.
    • Epithelial membrane antigen.
    • Cytokeratin.
    • Mesothelin.

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain

Coarse, partially calcified right pleural plaques, accompanied by massive right pleural effusion, causing total right lung collapse and mass effect.

Lobulated pleural soft tissue mass encasing the right lung. Associated erosion of the right 3rd rib anteriorly.

Calcified pleural plaques were noted bilaterally, indicating previous asbestos exposure.

questions.text: Criterion that differentiates exudative from transudative pleural effusion?
questions.correct_answer: B. High protein in pleural fluid
questions.explanation:
Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Respiratory failu

questions.text: A patient presents with acute epigastric pain and an increase in serum lipase levels. Three days after stabilization, a chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most common pathology behind the chest X-ray findings?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Non-cardiogenic pulmonary

Condition

Acute Pancreatitis with Non-cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema

Key Clinical Features

Acute epigastric pain, elevated serum lipase, systemic inflammation

Common Chest X-ray Findings

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema (due to increased capillary permeability)

Differential Diagnosis

Differentiated from cardiogenic pulmonary edema (increased PCWP), pulmonary embolism (more sudden respiratory compromise), and aspiration pneumonitis (associated with a history of aspiration)

Rationale

The systemic inflammatory response in acute pancreatitis can lead to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, a common complication in severe cases

questions.text: What is the expected finding in a patient with the following CXR?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Paradoxical breathing

Condition

Flail Chest

Key Clinical Features

Multiple rib fractures with a free-floating chest wall segment, leading to paradoxical movement of the chest during respiration

Expected Respiratory Pattern

Paradoxical breathing: inward movement of the chest wall segment during inspiration and outward during expiration

Differential Diagnosis

Differentiated from Kussmaul (metabolic acidosis), Apneustic (brainstem injury), and Bronchial breathing (lung consolidation)

Rationale

Paradoxical breathing is directly linked to the loss of chest wall stability due to rib fractures in flail chest

questions.text: Patient presents with recurrent lung infections and CXR is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Kartag

Condition

Kartagener syndrome

Key Features

Dextrocardia (situs inversus), chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis

Diagnosis

Confirmed by CXR showing dextrocardia and clinical symptoms

Distinguishing Factors

Presence of situs inversus and recurrent lung infections

questions.text: A patient presents with wheezing that improves with as-needed use of albuterol. Spirometry shows FEV1 ranging from 70% to 83%, and the patient experiences nighttime chest tightening twice a week. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Add an inh

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with increased breathlessness, cough, and sputum production over the last two days. She appears distressed and has a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for her immediate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate high-flow oxygen therapy to maintain oxygen saturation above 95%

options.label: B
options.text: Start nebulised bronchodilator therapy with salbutamol and ipratropium

options.label: D
options.text: Order a chest X-ray before any treatment is provided

questions.correct_answer: B. Start nebulised bronchodilator therapy with salbutamol and ipratropium
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Arterial blood gases

Assess severity of hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, acidaemia; guide oxygen therapy and ventilation.

Chest X-ray

Identify complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pleural effusion. (Option D ruled out)

Management

Details

Oxygen Therapy
  • Administer controlled oxygen at 24% or 28% to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa (60 mmHg) or SaO2 > 90%. (Option A ruled out)
  • Regular arterial blood gas monitoring to adjust therapy.

Bronchodilators
  • Use nebulised short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) with anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium).
  • If oxygen sensitivity is a concern, use compressed air for nebulisation.

Glucocorticoids
  • Administer oral prednisolone (30 mg for 10 days) to reduce symptoms and improve lung function.Reduces frequency and severity of exacerbations.
  • Consider osteoporosis prophylaxis for repeated courses.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Indicated for increased sputum purulence, volume, or breathlessness.
  • Use simple regimens (aminopenicillin, tetracycline, macrolide); co-amoxiclav in areas with β-lactamase organisms.

Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV)
  • Safe for mild to moderate respiratory acidosis; helps reduce intubation need and mortality.
  • Not suitable for patients unable to protect their airway.

Mechanical Ventilation
  • Consider if there is a reversible cause, no prior respiratory failure, or if NIV has failed/contraindicated.
  • Decisions should involve the patient, family, and GP.

Additional Therapy
  • Diuretics for peripheral oedema.
  • Limited evidence for intravenous aminophylline; consider arrhythmia risk.
  • Doxapram may be used short-term for low respiratory rates.

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic patient presented with fever, malaise, and a productive cough. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Patchy infiltrates as seen in pyogenic pneumonia

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the upper segment of the lower lobe and posterior segment of the upper lobe

questions.correct_answer: A. Patchy infiltrates as seen in pyogenic pneumonia

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anemia. Chest x-ray was done and given below. What is the diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with an 8-month history of shortness of breath and non-productive cough. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes for the past 30 years. On physical examination, clubbing is seen and fine crackles are heard on both sides during inspiration. You perform pulmonary function tests and it shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. The CT scan of the chest is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Histological Pattern

Associated Clinical Syndrome

Usual Interstitial Pneumonia

Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis

Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia

Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia

Acute Interstitial Pneumonia

Hamman-Rich Syndrome

Bronchiolitis Obliterans Organizing Pneumonia (BOOP)

Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia

Non-Specific Interstitial Pneumonia

Non-Specific Interstitial Pneumonia

Respiratory Bronchiolitis-Associated Lung Disease

Respiratory Bronchiolitis-Associated Interstitial Lung Disease

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic man presents after a fall. He is having a high fever, cough and breathing difficulty and appears confused. CXR shows lobar consolidation. Labs show elevated BUN and creatinine. Which is the most appropriate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Discharge home on Amoxicillin with Clavulanic acid

questions.explanation:
Status

Regimen



 

No comorbidities or risk factors for antibiotic resistance

Combination therapy with Amoxicillin + either Macrolide or Doxycycline

OR

Monotherapy with Doxycycline

OR

Monotherapy with a Macrolide


 

With comorbidities ± Risk factors for antibiotic resistance

Combination therapy with:

Amoxicillin /clavulanate or a Cephalosporin +

Macrolide or Doxycycline

OR

Monotherapy with respiratory fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin)

questions.text: A chronic cigarette smoker has now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient? Initial lung volumes were: FEV1-0.9L FVC-1.9L FEV1/FVC-0.4 After bronchodilation: FEV1-1.9L FVC-3.9L FEV1/FVC-0.4

options.label: B
options.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility

options.label: C
options.text: Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.correct_answer: D. Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume – 360 mL; frequency – 30 breaths/min; PEEP - 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2-90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows; paO2-50 mmHg; paCO2-38 mmHg; and pH-7.38. What is the next step?

A 5-year-old child presented with recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum. Chest X-ray showed bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Cystic fibrosis

Organ System

Pathological Features

Clinical Manifestations

Diagnostic Findings

Respiratory
  • Thick mucus plugging
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic inflammation
  • Submucosal gland hypertrophy
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Recurrent infections
  • Progressive dyspnea
  • Digital clubbing
  • Obstructive pattern on PFTs
  • Bronchiectasis on CT

Pancreatic
  • Duct obstruction
  • Acinar cell destruction
  • Fibrosis
  • Fat replacement
  • Malabsorption
  • Steatorrhea
  • Failure to thrive
  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
  • Low fecal elastase
  • Elevated fecal fat
  • Low vitamins A, D, E, K

Sweat Glands
  • Abnormal chloride transport
  • Normal gland structure
  • Salty-tasting skin
  • Heat intolerance
  • Salt depletion
  • Elevated sweat chloride
  • >60 mEq/L diagnostic

Hepatobiliary
  • Bile duct plugging
  • Focal biliary cirrhosis
  • Multilobular cirrhosis
  • Neonatal cholestasis
  • Portal hypertension
  • Gallstones
  • Elevated liver enzymes
  • Ultrasound changes

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. Chest X-ray shows a 3cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- CT-guided biopsy

Evaluation for Suspected Lung Mass

Non-Invasive Diagnostic Methods

Sputum Cytology
  • Non-invasive initial diagnostic test
  • Most useful for central lesions (Option C Ruled Out)
  • Higher yield in large, proximal tumors
  • Low sensitivity due to high tissue variability

CT Chest
  • Contrast-enhanced
  • Extension to upper abdomen (adrenal level)
  • Sensitivity: 55%, Specificity: 81%
  • Identifies tumor location, extent, and lymph node involvement
  • Lymph node ≥1cm in short axis considered suspicious

PET/PET-CT
  • Higher accuracy than CT (Sensitivity: 80%, Specificity: 88%)
  • Identifies metabolic activity and potential metastases
  • Reduces futile thoracotomies
  • Helpful in identifying recurrence post-therapy

Invasive Staging & Biopsy Methods

CT-Guided Transthoracic Biopsy
  • Preferred for peripheral lesions (Option A)
  • High diagnostic accuracy
  • Minimally Invasive
  • Risk of pneumothorax (especially in emphysematous patients)
  • Contraindicated if high bleeding risk or severe emphysema

EBUS-TBNA
  • CP-EBUS: Real-time sampling of mediastinal/hilar nodes
  • RP-EBUS: For smaller/peripheral lesions
  • Navigation bronchoscopy for mapped approach

Endoscopic-TBNA
  • Samples through esophageal wall
  • Accesses stations 2, 4, 7, 8, 9
  • Sensitivity: 89%, Specificity: 100%

Mediastinoscopy
  • Used after negative needle technique
  • Samples para-tracheal nodes
  • Sensitivity: 78%, Specificity: 100%
  • Mortality risk: 0.08%

VATS/RATS
  • For mediastinal lymph node sampling
  • Full dissection during lung resection
  • Minimally invasive approach

Cancer Type

Location

Primary Investigations

Additional Investigations

Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) - Adenocarcinoma

Peripheral/Outer regions of lung
  • CT-guided needle biopsy
  • PET-CT scan
  • Blood tests for tumor markers (CEA)
  • Molecular testing (EGFR, ALK, ROS1)
  • MRI brain (for staging)
  • Pulmonary function tests

NSCLC - Squamous Cell

Central/Main bronchi
  • Bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • Chest CT with contrast
  • Sputum cytology
  • Mediastinoscopy
  • Bone scan (if symptoms)
  • PD-L1 testing

Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC)

Central regions, rapid spread
  • CT chest/abdomen/pelvis
  • Bronchoscopy
  • Blood tests (ProGRP, NSE)
  • MRI brain (mandatory)
  • Bone marrow biopsy
  • Nuclear medicine scans

Large Cell Carcinoma

Any location
  • PET-CT scan
  • Core needle biopsy
  • Immunohistochemistry
  • Molecular profiling
  • EBUS-TBNA
  • Liquid biopsy

Carcinoid Tumors

Usually central airways
  • Octreotide scan
  • Bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • 24-hour urine 5-HIAA
  • Chromogranin A levels
  • MIBG scan
  • Endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion?

Correct Answer C- Rheumatoid arthritis

Causes of pleural effusion

Tranudative

Exudative

Both

  • Congestive heart failure (Option A)

  • Cirrhosis

  • Liver failure (Option B)

  • Nephrotic syndrome (Option D)

  • Peritoneal dialysis

  • SVC obstruction

  • Urinothorax

  • Pneumonia

  • Esophageal perforation

  • Pancreatic disease

  • Rheumatoid pleuritis (Option C)

  • Collagen vascular diseases:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Sjögren syndrome

  • Wegener Granulomatosis

Pulmonary embolism

Drugs induced

  • Nitrofurantoin

  • Dantrolene

  • Methysergide

  • Bromocriptine

  • Procarbazine

  • Amiodarone

  • Dasatinib

Normal

Flattened

Normal

questions.text: What is the cause of infertility in individuals with Kartagener's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Asth

Aspect

Kartagener's syndrome

Definition

A rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the abnormal structure and function of cilia, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance.

Underlying Cause
  • Defects in the structure or function of dynein arms, which are responsible for ciliary movement

Associated Conditions
  • Recurrent middle ear infections
  • Chronic otitis media
  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Kartagener's triad: Situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia in the outpatient setting?

Correct Option C - Azith

No Comorbidities or

Not received antibiotic in last 3 months

↓

Doxycycline (If macrolides is not available)

Co-morbid condition or

Taken Antibiotics in last 3 months

↓

Moxifloxacin or

b Lactam + Macrolides

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO 2 = 50, HCO 3 = 28 . What is the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Respiratory acidosis with metabolic

Acid-Base Disorder

pH

Primary Imbalance

Compensatory Response

Respiratory Acidosis

Low

Increased pCO2

Renal Compensation (Increased Bicarbonate reabsorption)

Respiratory Alkalosis

High

Decreased pCO2

Renal Compensation (Decreased Bicarbonate reabsorption)

Metabolic Acidosis

Low

Decreased Bicarbonate

Respiratory Compensation (Hyperventilation)

Metabolic Alkalosis

High

Increased Bicarbonate

Respiratory Compensation (Hypoventilation)

questions.text: Among the following choices, which organism is the most probable cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - A

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Obstructiv

Parameter

Findings

Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)

Decreased

Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)

Decreased (may be normal or slightly decreased)

FEV1/FVC Ratio

Decreased

Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR)

Decreased

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Normal or increased

Residual Volume (RV)

Increased

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Increased

Tidal Volume (TV)

Normal or slightly decreased

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough an significant weight loss . His chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP)

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with metastasis to the brain?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Lung

questions.text: A 45-year patient working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis . Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - A

questions.text: Which of the following is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Pneumoth

questions.text: N95 respirator is used for:
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Airborne precau

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Haemorrhag

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Bronch

questions.text: A young man presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, breathlessness, and blurring of vision while trekking on a mountain at an altitude of 5000 meters . He is unable to climb any further. Which of the following develops at high-altitude?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Respiratory alk

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic complaints of a productive cough in the morning . The expectoration is yellow, foul smelling and increases on turning from left to right side. Which of the following lung diseases is likely to be present ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Bronch

questions.text: A male patient with a history of chronic smoking presents with the complaint of dysphagia . Out of the following, which type of lung cancer is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Squamou

questions.text: Kartagener syndrome is associated with defects in which of the following structures?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - C
